content: I've added the "Tiling" tag.

Maybe you should consider adding more testcases (in particular tricky ones, such as (9,17)) as some incorrect approaches were able to pass.

Actually, I had already said that here (in the very first comment of the thread, several months ago) but none of my concerns were addressed.

As already mentioned below:
 - T6 = V6 & T7 = V7
 - there should be more testcases
 - and probably (much) harder ones (as is, it's not a "very hard" problem)

Note that this problem will easily be hardcodable anyway (values can easily be found on the internet). Have you considered, for instance, asking for the number of minimal solutions too?

Edited to fix typos and a few minor formatting issues.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: La contribution est originale, sympathique et assez compliquée.
Very hard
Great!
related paper: https://reader.elsevier.com/reader/sd/pii/S0097316596901041?token=6331FAD75AF09226F90036BC9FE47200EFCD20E467042ACF339F1D456A9A04E91C67DD83D124D8FAFAD6D9C3E275DCF6

Your sets 6 and 7 have the same test/validator, why is that?
I agree with LastRick about the difficulty, IMHO <50 is too small for very hard.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fine problem, only concern is the difficulty. It can be solved with DP and a list of special cases (e.g. 11 x 13), which is probably closer to "medium".
Is solution for this one simply brute-force? I can see some patterns when comparing odd and even lengths of sides, but I'm not certain on this one

It would be nice to differentiate test and validator 3 and 4, and add some edge cases based on your constraints :

33 33 -> 1
1 1 -> 1

39 1 -> 39
1 21 -> 21

15 45 -> 3
49 7 -> 7

49 41 -> 9
42 49 -> 5

also an image would be appropriate to visualize the problem (with a balise code should be nice !) :
 _ _ _ _ _ _ _
|       |     |
|   4   |  3  |
|       |_ _ _|
|_ _ _ _|     |
| 2 | 2 |  3  |
|_ _|_ _|_ _ _|
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
much harder than it looks!
Very interesting, maybe someone gonna find an explicit formula to resolve this problem ?
Look a bit hard to resolve
I don't understand what "squares with integer sides" are supposed to be. This is probably for initiates.
I don't think this is easy enough to be in a Clash of Code, but it seems really nice.
Interesting problem. Definitely would love to have this one. :)

Nice problem. It reminds some bin-packing ones.
It does not look easy but I will think about it...

Need to reword for clarity, e.g. change "find the smallest number of integer sided square that can completely fill the rectangle" to "find the minimum number of squares with integer sides needed to fill the rectangle" - completely is redundant because something isn't fill if it's incomplete.
Remove "Ligne 1:" because there's no line 2.
Agree that this doesn't seem "very hard" (albeit I haven't tried yet!).
Perhaps add a rationalisation for the example, e.g.:

111155
111155
111166
111166
222333444
222333444
222333444

The puzzle looks identical to the medium difficulty puzzle "Goro want chocolate" - https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/goro-want-chocolate.

Also, I passed that puzzle and tried some validators with my solution and solutions of some other people and some of your validators don't seem right, For example, "17 20" should be 8, not 7.

It is a more general version of the problem (in the other one, Goro splits a rectangle in two at each step, which strongly reduces the tiling options).
An optimal solution for 17x20 can be seen here: https://int-e.eu/~bf3/squares/view.html#20,17

thanks you for you advices, but I think you need to give it a go to realize that even if it's easy to understand it's kind of pretty hard to solve. And I think that it's a bit what make it a really good puzzle.

I agree with all this^

Provide a wider variety of tests, from small ones the user can check, to big ones that require an efficient algorithm.

Ideally the image + example would be one like (11, 13) where splitting into rectangles doesn't find the best solution.
related paper: https://reader.elsevier.com/reader/sd/pii/S0097316596901041?token=6331FAD75AF09226F90036BC9FE47200EFCD20E467042ACF339F1D456A9A04E91C67DD83D124D8FAFAD6D9C3E275DCF6

Talked about this problem with Euler yesterday, I think the best solution would be to just move the difficulty asap. IMO this site seriously needs to codify what defines "easy", "medium", etc now that the community can submit puzzles. In hindsight I shouldn't have approved it as very hard, I admit.

i have changed some testcase to avoid repetition and i agree on the fact that tha testcase are too small and giger numbers could force people to find an optimized solution. but i can't add big test cases if my solution can't sovle them and i have yet find an optimized solution.
if you have a good and fast way to solve this problem i'm happy to ear about

Ok I get it.
natural number sized squares maybe?
Or just give an example 1x1, 2x2, 3x3, etc... squares
or even simpler: the sides length must be a natural number

Integer sided makes me imagine squares with sides composed of integers.
Such as:
999
9..9
999

And from then on it makes absolutely no sense looking at the examples, hence the confusion.

It is to be kept in mind that there are people like me who never encountered the expression "integer sided" to mean the sides' size must be natural numbers.
OK but please consider my other points :-)
Aha, ok, thanks for the clarification. Disregard my comment, please, it's a completely different problem. And that's a great link, I wish I had it when I was solving Goro. :)
I followed the page script and data to see if you were giving away the problem but no dice, the solutions are precomputed and encoded :D
Sure, no surprise. That said, some algorithms and implementations are indeed available on the same site (https://int-e.eu/~bf3/squares/).

In fact, this was supposed to be the follow-up to Goro that I never got around to :D

"Shang Tsung desires fancy candy", so to say.
